dt: {bc}blunt in manner or speech often to the point of ungracious harshness

pt: {sc}bluff{/sc} {sc}blunt{/sc} {sc}brusque{/sc} {sc}curt{/sc} {sc}crusty{/sc} {sc}gruff{/sc} mean abrupt and unceremonious in speech and manner. {sc}bluff{/sc} connotes good-natured outspokenness and unconventionality.
{sc}blunt{/sc} suggests directness of expression in disregard of others' feelings.
{sc}brusque{/sc} applies to a sharpness or ungraciousness.
{sc}curt{/sc} implies disconcerting shortness or rude conciseness.
{sc}crusty{/sc} suggests a harsh or surly manner sometimes concealing an inner kindliness.
{sc}gruff{/sc} suggests a hoarse or husky speech which may imply bad temper but more often implies embarrassment or shyness.

et: French {it}brusque{/it}, from Italian {it}brusco{/it}, from Medieval Latin {it}bruscus{/it} butcher's-broom (plant with bristly twigs)
shortdef: blunt in manner or speech often to the point of ungracious harshness
